results.title: I'm not too famous at it: a definition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, Robert Anderson and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Learning Series”.
The title was named by Robert, a bright nine year old, who lacks eye-hand coordination, has difficulty appreciating the characteristics of shapes and forms, has language difficulties of various kinds, who has poor gross motor coordination and other problems. While defining and describing these learning deficits indirectly shows somthing of the process of remediation.

results.title: Jewels of the Kimberley
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Mabey, Rio and Mitch Matthews
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
The original jewels in the Kimberley in Australia’s far north west were the hardy pioneer cattlemen and women who crossed the Continent with their herds to establish themselves as Kings in Grass Castles. They were followed by gold prospectors and farmers who opened up the mighty Ord River Irrigation Scheme. The newest jewels are diamonds. They were discovered by the new prospectors who are now reaping rich rewards for the millions of dollars they spent prospecting for their jewels. Rated: G

results.title: Rainbow's End
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
Every goldrush seems to begin with stories of people, picking up nuggets by the handful. This is a nostalgic journey to the richest square mile of real estate in the world. Jack Absalom traces the “Golden Rainbow” that the early diggers followed on their quest that would set them up for life. Rated: G

results.title: Tax is not a four letter word
results.creator_credit: Michael Mills, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A musical cartoon produced for the Department of National Revenue, Canada. It is about the most misunderstood servant of us all, the income tax collector. But in this film he no longer remains unloved, unsung, once people understand that the money he collects is really for everyone’s benefit. A bright, amusing film for any time of year, tax time or not.

results.title: The Rise of the Crocodile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
In recent years crocodiles have made quite an impact - 10 people have lost their lives. Living in the far north of Australia has been described as living inside a giant game park - no fences between man and beast, with the balance tipping more and more in the crocodile’s favour. Jack Absalom talks with the people of the Northern Territory’s Top End about their experiences with an increasing crocodile population. Rated: G

results.title: Jack Absalom's outback Australia series
results.creator_credit: John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey, Timothy Sullivan and Sorena
results.brief_description: The inimitable Jack Absalom, painter and outback traveller extraordinaire, visits remote areas of Australia, giving us his personal view of the history and unique character of each area.

results.title: Tati shorts
results.brief_description: The characters in these three short films will be familiar territory to fans of actor/director Jacques Tati. “Soigne ton Gauche=Watch your Left” (12 mins. 1936) directed by Rene Clement, focuses on a boxer whose training suffers considerable upheaval when he is joined in the ring by Tati bearing many traits of what would later become the Hulot character. This film has some French dialogue but the soundtrack is ambient rather than specific. “L’Ecole des Facteurs=School for Postmen” (15 mins. 1947) sees Tati approach his studies in a confused and enthusiastic manner. This character would go on to reap global fame as Francois the Postman in ‘Jour de Fete’. In “Cours du Soir=Evening Classes” (28 mins. 1967) Tati’s portrayal of a teacher presents an amalgam of Hulot and Francois allowing both characters full comic reign in the classroom.

results.title: Techniques
results.creator_credit: Eve Cotton and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: By analysing and comparing great paintings from different periods, this series provides a unique introduction to art. This program examines the techniques used to produce different styles of painting. The techniques examined are: fresco, tempera and oil, water colour, pastel and prints.

results.title: Teamwork in farm research
results.creator_credit: George Bloomfield, Barrie Angus McLean and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An example of the modern approach of agricultural scientists to problems that affect the farming industry, the film gives an account of how a coumarin-free variety of sweet clover, under certain silage conditions, developed a poisonous mould. From a few test seedlings, through a whole program of cross-breeding, the film shows how the nutritionally safe “Cumino” variety of sweet clover was finally produced in commercial quantities.
